{{complex}} '''Graphics''' (from [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] Graphikos {{lang|grc|[[:wiktionary:γραφικός|γραφικός]]}}) are [[visual]] presentations on some surface, such as a wall, [[canvas]], computer screen, paper, or stone. It includes everything that relates to creation of [[signs]], [[charts]], [[logos]], [[graphs]],[[drawings]], [[Line Art]], [[symbols]], [[geometric]] designs and so on. [[Graphic Design]] is the art or profession of combining text, pictures, and ideas in advertisements, publication, or website. The aim of graphic is to [[brand]], inform, and have a specific effect on its audience.<ref> see: Oxford Dictionary [http://www.askoxford.com/concise_oed/graphicdesign?view=uk], Merriam Webster Dictionary [http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/Graphic%20Design], and Random House Dictionary [http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/graphic_design]</ref>
== History of Graphics ==
Hundreds of graphic designs of animals by the primitive people in the [[Chauvet cave]], in the south of France,which were drawn more than 30,000 B.C. <ref> See: Chauvet, Jean-Marie; Eliette Brunel Deschamps, Christian Hillaire (1996). Dawn of Art: The Chauvet Cave. Paul G. Bahn (Foreword), Jean Clottes (Epilogue). New York: Harry N. Abrams. ISBN 0810932326</ref>, as well as similar designs in the Lascaux cave of France that were drawn more than 14,000 B.C.<ref> see: The Cave of Lascaux, by Mario Ruspoli, Harry N. Abrams (May 1, 1987), ISBN-10: 0810912678, ISBN-13: 978-0810912670 </ref>, or the designs of the primitive hunters in the rocks of Bhimbetka in India that were drawn more than 7,000 B.C. <ref>{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/pg.cfm?cid=31&id_site=925|title=Rock Shelters of Bhimbetka|publisher=World Heritage Site|accessdate=2007-02-15}}</ref>, and the Aboriginal Rock Art, in Kakadu National Park of Australia <ref> see: the Encyclopedia Britannica : Aboriginal Rock Art, Ubirr Art Site, Kakadu National Park, Australia [http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/309883/Kakadu-National-Park]</ref>, and many other rock or cave paintings in other parts of the world show that graphics have a very long history which is shared among humanity. This history together with the history of writing which was emerged in 3000-4000 B.C. are at the foundation of the Graphic Art. === Rock and Cave Art === <gallery> Image:Chauvethorses.jpg | Drawing of horses in the Chauvet cave. Image:Lascaux2.jpg| Drawing of a horse in the Lascaux cave. Image:Bhimbetka rock paintng1.jpg| A rock drwing in Bhimbetka India. Image:Kakadu-painting-hero.jpg| Aboriginal Rock Art, Ubirr Art Site, Kakadu National Park, Australia </ref> </gallery>

In the end, twenty-six of the participants composed thirty-seven poems.Richard Kurt Kraus, Brushes with Power (Berkeley: University of California Press, 1991), 27.</ref> Image:Scribe's exercise tablet 1.jpg| Scribe's exercise tablet with hieratic text. == First use Graphics in Books - Arabesque ==
The religious books have used graphics extensively. Among these books are the [[Bibles]] that have been created in the monasteries in [[Ireland]], [[Scotland]], and [[England]]. here are four examples. These graphics in these books have been influenced by the Arabesque. Muslims who, because of their religious beliefs, could not paint human bodies or animals, like Romans or Greeks, used geometrical and abstract designs to decorated the their holy books, and their mosques. Europeans were influenced by these designs. <ref>See Larousse: [http://www.larousse.fr/encyclopedie/#larousse/763/102/arabesques]</ref>
<gallery> Image:LindisfarneFol27rIncipitMatt.jpg|A page from Lindisfarne Bible, 7th or 8th century Image:LichfieldGospelsEvangelist.jpg| A graphic decoration from Lichfield gosppel 8th century Image:KellsDecoratedInitial.jpg| A graphic decoration in the Book of Kells, 6-9th century Image:BookOfDurrowBeginMarkGospel.jpg| Opening page of Book of Durrow, 6-9th century </gallery>
=== Graphics in Quran === In Islamic countries the graphic designs can be found in their holy book Quran. The writers used black ink and golden paper to write with an angled alphabet, Called Kuffi. Such writings appeared in 8th century, and reached their apex in 1oth century. Later on decoration of margin, page and other graphic techniques added to beautify the book. In 12th century the Naskh alphabet was invented that instead of angled lines used curves. Other styles such as Mohaghegh, Reyhan, Sols, Reghaa, and Toghii was added later on <ref> :Drogin, Marc Medieval Calligraphy: Its History and Technique. New York: Dover Publications, 1980.Miner, Dorothy E. compiler, 2000 Years of Calligraphy, an Exhibition Organized [1965] by the Baltimore Museum of Art, et al. New Jersey: Rowman & Littlefield, 1972. </ref> <gallery> Image:Qur'an folio 11th century kufic.jpg| A page from a Persian Quran in 11th century . Image:AndalusQuran.JPG| Graphic art in an Egyptian Quran of 9-10th century. Image:Large Koran.jpg| An Iranian Quran of 15th century found in Uzbekistan. Image:Abbasid Koran folio from Egypt.jpg| A Quran with Kuffi Alphabeth of 12th century. </gallery>

== Birth of the Modern Graphic Design == Perhaps it would be possible to consider William Morris the father of modern graphics. In the second half of 19th century his Kelmscott Press produced many of the graphic designs, and created a collector market for this kind of art. In Oxford he was associated with artists like Morris, Burne-Jones, and Dante Gabriel Rossetti. Together they formed the Pre-Raphaelites group, which their ideas influenced the modern graphic design considerably.<ref> See: Encarta [http://encarta.msn.com/encyclopedia_761563639/William_Morris.html], and Larousse [http://www.larousse.fr/encyclopedie/#larousse/1170/102/Morris] </ref>
<gallery> Image:Morris Peacock and Dragon Fabric 1878 v2.jpg|This fabric design called Peacock and Dragon, which is the work of William Morris (1878) is a beautiful example of decorative graphic design. Such designs was revived during the 1960s with the emergence of the hippie movement. Image:Morris Tulip and Willow design 1873.jpg| This Morris Tulip and Willow design (1873) is another example of decorative graphics. The powerful diagonal blue, with only some suggestion of orange creates a harmonious color scheme that can be used effectively in the design of a poster or other graphic design media. Image:Kelmscott Press - The Nature of Gothic by John Ruskin (first page).jpg|This is the first page of The Nature of Gothic by John Ruskin which was published by Kelmscott Press of William Morris. The decorative design was the revival of the Gothic style in graphic design. Image:Rubaiyat Morris Burne-Jones Manuscript.jpg| This book of Poetry, called Rubaiyat, by the famous Persian poet Omar Khayyam, is an example of early modern graphic design cooperation, with a graphic composition of calligraphy and decorative design by Morris and painting by Burne-Jones. </gallery>
== Mondrian's Minimalism Revolution == The Dutch painter Piet Mondrian in the years 1920-21 courageously introduced the style of minimalism in painting. His simple geometric compositions, together with the use of only three basic colors, blue, yellow, and red, in combination with black and white created a new venue for the graphic designers. He demonstrated that with simple relocation of these colors, and experiment with the proportionality of various square surfaces one can achieve extremely different ambiances and various feelings. For the graphic designers who intend to convey a message with a minimum interference from the extraneous elements his experiment in minimalism was a valuable gift. <ref>See: Piet Modrian, Colour, Structure and Symbolism: An Essay, by LOCHER, HANS CH-3006 Bern, Switzerland, Verlag Gachnang & Springer, Switzerland. 1994. 3906127443, Piet Mondrian, life and work, by Michel Seuphor, Harry N. == Man Communicates with Pictures ==
<gallery> Image:Perros No.svg| This is an Spanish sign for "Dogs Are Not Allowed Here". This kind of sign is called pictogram <ref> See: Larousse [http://www.larousse.fr/encyclopedie/#larousse/60374/11/pictogramme]</ref> The red circle with a diagonal line crossing it coveys the idea of "Not Allowed", and is called an Ideogram sign. <ref> لاروس [http://www.larousse.fr/encyclopedie/#larousse/41318/11/id%C3%A9ogramme]</ref> The advantages of these signs are that one does not need to be able to read or does not need to be familiar with the culture, and the language in order to understand the message. Image:Stop sign MUTCD.svg|This is the STOP sign in many of the European countries. These type of signs are called phonogram <ref> [http://www.larousse.fr/encyclopedie/#larousse/59970/11/phonogramme]</ref> Obviously one needs to be able to read the sign, and to be familiar with the language in order to understand its message. Image:Abe-Rebus French.png|A '''rebus''' ([[Latin]]: "by things") is a kind of word puzzle which uses pictures to represent words or parts of words, such as "T,4,2" instead of "tea for two". The above French rebus says: A big bishop full of appetite have crossed Paris without lunch(Un grand abbé, rempli d'appétit a traversé Paris sans souper); or, literally: one big AB (un grand AB) full of little "a"s (rempli d'a petits) |a crossed by i (a traversé par i) |100 under p (100 sous p) <ref>See: Larousse [http://www.larousse.fr/encyclopedie/#larousse/66167/11/r%C3%A9bus], and Encarta [http://encarta.msn.com/encnet/refpages/search.aspx?q=r%C3%A9bus]</ref> Rebus has played an important role in creation of alphabets. Image:Armoiries Actuelles Espagne.svg|This is the heraldic sign of the Bourbons of Spain. The heraldic signs exist from ancient times. For example Romans used eagle as their symbol, French used fleur de lis, and Persians used the sign of their god, Ahura Mazda. After the second half of the 12th century these signs became prominent in the west with the establishment of feudal regimes. Given that the faces of the fully plate-armored knights were hidden these signs were used to identify them. The signs were created under strict rules and traditions. <ref>See: Encarta [http://encarta.msn.com/encyclopedia_761565530/Heraldry.html] </ref> </gallery> === Logos and Trade Marks ===
A '''trade mark''', identified by the symbols [[trademark symbol|™]] and [[registered trademark symbol|®]], or '''mark''' is a distinctive sign or indicator used by an individual, company or other entity to identify its products or services and to distinguish them from those of other producers. A trademark is a type of intellectual property, and typically a name, word, phrase, [[logo]], [[symbol]], design, image, or a combination of these elements.<ref> See: the Random House Unabridged Dictionary, © Random House, Inc. 2006.</ref>
<gallery> Image:Coca-Cola logo.svg| This graphic design of the Coca-Cola logo is the work of Frank Mason Robinson who created it in 1885<ref>There is no proof as to who originally wrote it, but master Penman Louis Madarasz(1859-1910) was said to have told one of his students that the work was his. When the work was created Madarasz had a mail-order business and could easily have done it, and the writing style is similar to his. In the book "An Elegant Hand" by William E Henning, it states that Frank Mason Robinson, who was the bookkeeper of the firm oringinated the name Coca-Cola and specified that it be written in Spencerian script. In a 1914 court case, Robinson testified that he was "practically the originator" and that "some engraver here by the name of Frank Ridge was brought into it"</ref>. This old Logotype has been around more than a century, which could be regarded as a measure its success. A successful logotype will create a sense of loyalty among the clienteles. <ref> Minority Report: The Cola clash of civilisations, by Jerome Talyor, The Independent, Thursday, 10 July 2008 </ref>
Image:VW-Logo.png| This is the logotype of Volkswagen which is easily recognizable all around the world <ref> [http://www.logoorange.com/logodesign-V.php]</ref> and is created by Franz Xaver Reimspiess. The simplicity of design with a strong composition created by the repetition of the V-formes inside a circle, provides a compelling visual impact . <ref> Volkswagen History to Hobby: All the Facts - All the Fun, by Bob Cropsey, Jersey Classic Publishing; 1 edition (August 30, 2005), ISBN-10: 0976526107 , ISBN-10: 0976526107. In praise of the CND logo, by Jonathan Glancey, guardian.co.uk, [http://www.guardian.co.uk/artanddesign/artblog/2008/apr/09/cndlogo] </ref>
Image:Google.png| Google is a young high-tech company, and its logotype created by Ruth Kedar reminds us of the Mondrian minimalism. Kedar has emphasized the playfulness of her design, and its simplicity that conveys an illusion of non-design. According to her " The colors evoke memories of child play, but deftly stray from the color wheel strictures so as to hint to the inherent element of serendipity creeping into any search results page ... The texture and shading of each letter is done in an unobtrusive way resulting in lifting it from the page while giving it both weight and lightness. <ref> Google Logo Design and History, [http://www.dinesh.com/History_of_Logos/Worlds_Best_Brands_and_Logos/Google_Logo_Design_and_History/] Read Kedar interview here: [http://blog.wired.com/underwire/2008/01/the-brains-behi.html] </ref>
Image:MSN logo.svg| The simple design in this trademark of MSN (The Microsoft Network) brings to mind the idea of internet browsing by the pertinent image of the journey of a butterfly from one flower to another in search of nectar. This Is a good example of conveying a clear message with a minimum interference of extraneous elements of design. </gallery>
=== Signs of Culture and Peace ===

== Information Signs: ISOTYPE and the Viennese Method == In 1921, Otto Neurath, an Austrian social scientist, introduced graphic design in order to facilitate the understanding of various social ad economical trends through the creative use of statistical charts. In 1924, Neurath advocated the establishment of the Museum of Economy and Society, an institution for public education and social information. In May 1925, the Museum's first graphical displays was opened to the public. The exhibition showed various complicated social and economical trends, and by using charts which were intuitive and interesting made those concepts easy to grasp. This style of presentation at the time was called the Viennese method, but now it is known as ISOTYPE charts. <ref>See : Stroom Den Haag [http://www.stroom.nl/paginas/pagina.php?pa_id=6422177] .</ref> ‎

== Placards and Posters == Placard and posters existed from the ancient times. The Greek ''axons'' and the Roman ''Albums'', with their decorative designs and announcements, were quite similar to today's posters. In ancient Greece the name of athletes, and games schedules were written on columns that were slowly turning on an axis. Romans used whitewashed walls in their markets in which sellers, money lenders, and slave traders wrote their announcements and advertised for their products, and to attract the attention of customers they added an attractive design. <ref>See: Larousse [http://www.larousse.fr/encyclopedie/#larousse/1441/11/affiche ]</ref> With the invention of printing, in 1440, and particularly the development of the lithographic process, invented by a Czech named Alois Senefelder in 1798 in Austria, creation of poster become feasible. Although handmade posters existed before, they were mainly used for government announcements. William Caxton, who in 1477 started a printing company in England produced the first printed poster. <ref>See: Encarta [http://encarta.msn.com/encyclopedia_761572424/William_Caxton.html] </ref> In 1870, the advertising poster emerged. <ref>In the 19th and 20th century artists like Jules Chéret, Daumier, Manet, Picasso, Ben Shahn, Norman Rockwell, Alexandre Steinlen, Alphonse Mucha, and Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec made compelling posters advertising, products entertainments and restaurants. Matt Morgan's circus advertisements (c.1890) started the American poster, and this was followed by Edward Penfield, Will H. Bradley, Maxfield Parrish, Howard Chandler Christie, James Montgomery Flagg, Charles Dana Gibson, and Harrison Fisher. </ref><ref>See: M. Rickards, The Rise and Fall of the Poster (1971); J. Barnicoat, A Concise History of Posters: 1870–1970 (1972); D. Ades, The Twentieth Century Poster (1984); J. Barnicoat, Posters: A Concise History (1985).</ref>
=== Chromolithography and Emergence of Modern Poster ===
After centuries of black ink on white paper, the invention of chromolithography in the US around 1840 revolutionized the art of poster. Because of its low production costs, over the 50 years after the American Civil War, millions of chromolithographs were printed and were sold for under $10. Louis Prang, a Bostonian, produced fine-art subjects, such as still lifes, landscapes, and classical subjects.<ref> see: Gallo, Max, The Poster in History, (2002) W.W.</ref> Nevertheless , it was only after Jules Chéret posters, in 1847, that the potential of this technical process for creation of artistic posters was realized. <ref>See : apanese Posters: The First 100 Years, Richard S. Thornton, Design Issues, Vol. 6, No. 1, Design in Asia and Australia (Autumn, 1989), pp. 4-14</ref> ==== Jules Chéret ==== <gallery> Image:Cheret, Jules - Le Pays des Fees (pl 181).jpg| Chéret's posters elevated advertisement to an art form.In 1858 he printed his first color poster in France. He ultimately became known as "the father of modern lithography", as well as the "Father of the Poster". Chéret revolutionized the composition of posters, using the design as the dominant features while reducing text to a minor explanatory role.
Image:Cheret, Jules - Les Saxoleine.jpg| Chéret's style gradually evolved from the complex Victorian decorative graphics into a simpler compositional design in which large central figures were prominent in the motif with simplified backgrounds, and large surfaces of vivid colour. Hand-lettered titles were used in harmony with the design.<ref>نگاه کنید به : History of Modern Design: Graphics and Products Since the Industrial Revolution, By David Raizman, Published by Laurence King Publishing, 2003,ISBN 1856693481,9781856693486, </ref>.<ref>See : The Poster as Art; Jules Cheret and the Struggle for the Equality of the Arts in Late Nineteenth-Century France, by Bradford R. Collins, 1985, The MIT Press. </ref>
Image:Cheret, Jules - Carnivale Poster.jpg| His large posters displayed free-spirited women which earned him the title of "father of the women's liberation." The women of Chéret's posters, playful, elegant and lively were very different from previously depicted prostitutes or puritans.
